text: Mary Baker Eddy (July 16, 1821 â€“ December 3, 1910) was the founder of Christian Science, a new religious movement in the United States in the latter half of the 19th century. Eddy wrote the movement's textbook Science and Health with Key to the Scriptures (first published 1875) and founded the Church of Christ, Scientist in 1879. She also founded the Christian Science Publishing Society (1898), which continues to publish a number of periodicals, including The Christian Science Monitor (founded in 1908). Baker died of pneumonia at her home in Newton, Massachusetts on December 3, 1910 at the age of 89."Mrs. Eddy Dies Of Pneumonia; No Doctor Near", The New York Times, December 5, 1910: "Mrs. Mary Baker Eddy, founder of the Church of Christ, Scientist, died Saturday night at 10:45 o'clock. The death was kept a secret until this morning, when a city medical examiner was called in. It was first publicly announced at the Mother Church this morning. Mrs. Eddy was in her ninetieth year." ==References== ==Other websites== *Mary Baker Eddy Library *The Mary Baker Eddy Science Institute *Mary Baker Eddy and Basic teachings of Christian Science, christianscience.com *The Longyear Museum Category:1821 births Category:1910 deaths Category:Deaths from pneumonia Category:Infectious disease deaths in Massachusetts Category:Christian Scientists Category:American abolitionists Category:American feminists Category:American human rights activists Category:American theologians Category:Writers from New Hampshire Category:Writers from Massachusetts
title: Mary Baker Eddy
